solution:
(a)
$(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a})\cdot\mathbf{a}=0$ describes a plane, to which the vector $\mathbf{a}$ is normal. Furthermore, the plane is offset from the origin by a distance $\mathbf{a}$.
(b)
Expanding parentheses, we have $$r^2 = \mathbf{a}\cdot\mathbf{r} = a \, r \cos\theta$$ If $\mathbf{r}\parallel\mathbf{a}$ then $\cos\theta=1$ and so $r=a$. If $\mathbf{r}\perp\mathbf{a}$ then $\cos\theta=1$ and so $r=0$. If $\cos\theta=-1$ (i.e. $\mathbf{r}$ is anti-parallel to $\mathbf{a}$) then $r=-a$, which is not allowed. The surface swept out by $\mathbf{r}$ is $r=a\,\cos\theta$ with $\theta\in[-\pi/2,\pi/2]$.
Geometrically, $\mathbf{a}$ describes the direction and length of this weird 3D shape (name?).
statement:
The vector $\mathbf{r}$, starting at the origin, terminates at and specifies the point in space $(x,y,z)$. Find the surface swept out by the tip of $\mathbf{r}$ if

(a)
$(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a})\cdot\mathbf{a}=0$. Characterize $\mathbf{a}$ geometrically.
(b)
$(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a})\cdot\mathbf{r}=0$. Describe the geometric role of $\mathbf{a}$.
The vector $\mathbf{a}$ is constant (in magnitude and direction).
